Fun fact: For anyone who watched the Bigfoot walking video, is not actually Bigfoot. It's actually a man in a costume, but the thing is... All of us believed that was actually what we thought it was claimed to be, but it's a man in the costume. Cause the man actually told the truth, but the thing is.. that costume should've been moving like a person rather than an ape, the muscle movement were more ape like than human. And they captured a creature that everybody described what Nessie was, and what's more scary is that we actually have a closeup of it's flippers. I honestly believe in any sea cryptids. The ocean so vast and mysterious like another world beneath our own.
My great-grandparents were Christian missionaries to Tibet from 1925 to 1940.  They were always skeptical of things like cryptids, until the very end of their time in East Asia.  At the time, Tibet was extremely difficult to access, as one had to spend weeks on mountain trails from the nearest railhead at the city of Yunnan-Fu (now called Kunming) in the southwestern part of non-Tibetan China.  The family had decided to leave for the USA in 1940, due to the difficulty of getting funding and supplies from home as a result of the ongoing war between Japan and China, and fears (later proven to be well-founded) that Japan would go to war with the US and completely block any route by which they could return to the States.  They were leaving Tibet and entering China near the top of a high mountain pass, when my great-grandmother and my grandfather (who was a boy of 10 years at the time and had lived 9 of them in Tibet), at the head of the caravan of riding horses and pack animals, saw a figure on the mountainside above them.  It was walking upright, and was completely covered in blue-gray hair.  When they stopped their horses to observe the figure, it appeared to notice them and quickly dashed away to hide behind an old rockslide on the mountain slope, running upright as a human would.  For the rest of their lives, they were convinced that what they saw was a yeti.  It would have had to be a half-grown one, as it was only about four feet tall, the same height as my 10-year-old grandfather (they made the comparison by having him climb up to where the figure had been standing when they first saw it).  The Tibetan horsemen who owned and managed the horses and donkeys carrying the family's luggage over the mountains accepted the figure as a yeti as a matter of course.  My family, who, as I mentioned before, were skeptical of things like cryptids, tried to consider other possibilities before accepting that.  The area was very remote and lonely, with no settlements within several days' journey, which made the idea that the figure could have been a person in a costume (or just a fur coat) playing a prank on them extremely unlikely.  Another suggestion (one that scientists my grandfather later told his account to believed), that the figure was a Tibetan Blue Bear, was inconsistent with the fact that the figure had walked and run in an upright, bipedal fashion, while a bear might have stood upright to observe its surroundings it would have dropped to all fours when it ran away.  While there were two species of monkeys that lived in the general region, both of them had tails, were only found below the tree line (far below that high mountain pass) and were significantly smaller than four feet in height.  The figure had been tailless.  Thus, they had to conclude that they saw a half-grown yeti.

Im tasmanian, my great grandmother (passed a few years ago) saw the last thylacine in captivity as a child. She recalled it really upsetting her, she hated seeing it, the last of its kind, locked in a metal and concrete prison as nothing more than a spectacle. Our poor tigers were the worst treated animals down here, the entire state feels nothing but regret for what we did to them. Ive heard a few people, usually middle aged, talk about seeing a wild one after the official declaration of its extinction. Not sure if i believe them or not, but with how much untouched and unreachable land there is down here in tassie, i wouldnt be surprised if even after the call was made that they were all gone, they kept dragging on in microscopic numbers perhaps even into the late 80s. When you mentioned the Michigan Dogman, that brought back memories from when I was little. My grandparents said not to go into the woods at night or else the dogman would get me. A cow was attacked by a panther (she survived), and they said it must‚Äôve been the dogman. My grandma‚Äôs friend said she saw the dogman walking on the side of the road by their house in outside of Grand Rapids. I was a little girl when I saw the news about the chupacabra livestock drainings. I have no idea how I managed to not get any sort of fear or trauma out of them, considering that Latin American news outlets didn‚Äôt exactly sensor the brutalities they showed on screen. They filmed the dead animals and showed up close how they became completely devoid of blood from one day to the next. I even remember that early reptilian sketches, and even the few weeks in which a non-regional bird was spotted in the metro area and people chased it down thinking it was the chupacabra. I was so surprised to learn it was born in the 90s, it must‚Äôve blown up in popularity super quick because I saw it referenced everywhere in the 2000s when I moved to the United States. I live in jersey and the way I always heard the jersey devil story was that mother Leeds practiced witchcraft and when she found out she was pregnant she predicted that the child would be a devil since it would be her 13th child. When the child was born it came out as a demon creature with hoofs wings and a horse head and it killed mother Leeds and all the rest of the children and then went on to terrorize the people of the pine barrens. One of the most famous sightings was when a guy returning from a hunting trip or something like that saw one run off the side of a highway, got out of his car, and took a photo of the footprint. There was also the Maine cabin incident that Mr. Ballin covered as well as the Land Between the Lakes incident. Both of which are generally ascribed to the Dogman. They are also found in some niche native folklore and on totem poles.

31:15 that isn‚Äôt how dogman began. Legends of dogman (several names were used) date back long before the DJ and are accepted by many First Nations people. The DJ simply made it famous in pop culture.

The Myakka Ape photos are most definitely NOT of a Ripley's BION exhibit. While the figure is compared to the old Wisconsin Dells Ripley's Bigfoot for its posture and extensive hair, the two share no further significant features, with the Myakka Ape demonstrating far greater detail which is consistent with historical reports from the South East, (more orangutan-like, but with tusks). It also demonstrates fine movements consistent with a startled primate, between photos.

26:32 wait the Jackalopes not a real thing
There's a disease in rabbits called kappapapillomavirus 2 or Shope papilloma virus (SPV). It causes horn-like tumors to grow on or near the rabbit's head. At a distance, it could be mistaken for antlers. That might be where the original sightings of the Jackalope came from.  Also, I'm very disappointed in your placement of the Kraken. Invertebrate cryptids need love too. :D

I just realized something relating to the Skunk Ape.  So, a FOUL ODOR.... In the EVERGLADES - essentially a MASSIVE COMPLEX OF SWAMPS AND MARSHLANDS that are filled to the brim with COUNTLESS HOSTILE, DANGEROUS AND AGGRESSIVE ANIMALS, PLANTS AND CONDITIONS... Which often PRECEDES SIGHTINGS AND ENCOUNTERS of a TERRIFYING AND HOSTILE CREATURE who's mere existence is otherwise debated....  What I'm getting at is that maybe, JUST~ maybe, the Skunk Ape might actually be the result of natural gas leaking into the area, causing people to have hallucinations that are then shaped by a combination of the already dangerous environment AND stories about the Skunk Ape! Somebody got gassed back in the day, had a REALLY bad trip, thought they saw a huge, aggressive and stinky ape, which from there entered the local cultural zeitgeist!  But hey, that's just a theory! A *CRYPTID THEORY!!!* Thanks for reading! xD

Look, laugh all you like, but I will go to my grave believing in the jackalope. My wife (who was my girlfriend at the time this event took place) and I were on our way to a Larping event in Florida, and we got lost and turned about. We somehow ended up on this little dirt road out in this swamp, the last sign of civilization that we had seen being some little rinky dink trailer park. While we were looking for a place to turn around, it leapt right in front of our car in full blast of the headlights, sat up and looked right at us. Then it dashed back into the brush on the right hand side of the road. It looked like it had a six-point rack on the head of a cane cutter rabbit. For a moment my wife and I just sat there in stunned silence. Then she said "What the hell did I just see?" I said "If I believed in such a thing... I'd say that was goddammed jackalope..." we both laughed and then tried to rationalize it. Rabbit with sticks caught in its fur, so on and so on... but nah. I know what the heck we saw.

17:27 would just like to add my knowledge of why sea monsters and tales of island sized creatures in the sea. The reason for these stories is because fishermen and sailors would go out in the sea maybe spot a huge (migration? School?) Of fish or whales and only see the outline of the group so it appeard much larger than they actually were something they actually do to protect from predators kind of like zebras and how they hang out in a pack and the stripes make it hard to tell where one starts and the other begins.

vid starts at 10:25 your welcome
The Loch Ness monster is just a greenland shark. It's the only logical explanation.  Sightings in the loch go back hundreds of years before the now defunct "Surgeon's Photo" of 1941. Greenland sharks, usually arctic creatures, are deep depth dwellers, and are known to travel as far south as Scotland. And the loch does have access to the ocean in certain times of the year. They can reach up to 20 feet in length, and are able to handle the loch's frigid-ass temperatures. It's a far better theory than the locals claim that it's a long extinct marine reptile, lol. A notably air breathing marine reptile, at that. If such a thing were in the loch, we'd know for sure. Cause it would be surfacing to breathe every few mins. The fact that something is there is practically undeniable, from all the sightings and even attacks going back to the Middle Ages, and the sonar hits we've gotten off of large objects swimming in the loch. Something is there. We just don't know what. Dolphins and seals also make their way into the loch from time to time. But again, air breathers; so known factors. Greenland sharks make the most logical sense given the evidence criteria.

I‚Äôm not one who necessarily believes in Cryptids, except for one.  Back in 2013, my family and I took a spring break trip to Punta Cana, Dominican Republic. After we left the airport and took a bus ride to our resort, something caught my eye as we took a corner. It appeared to be a relatively small to medium sized dog-like figure standing by the road just outside the brush and weeds. It was nearly completely hairless and had what I could only describe as razor sharp teeth showing in its horrific grin. It‚Äôs eyes were closed and it was the freakiest thing I had ever seen. The image of that creature showing its vampire like teeth is burnt in my mind, and I still can‚Äôt explain anything else that it could have been but that of the Chupacabra.

So I‚Äôm Aussie, I moved to Tasmania a few years ago, and studied the Tasmanian Tiger as part of a project in University.   When Tasmania was first discovered, colonists pretty much found it to be perfect for farming given how good the grass and stuff was, it would eventually become the home of one of the biggest wool industries in the world. So, Essentially, The Thylacine is only native to Tassie, they were a marsupial, which took everyone by shock because humans found marsupials to be inferior animals given they couldn‚Äôt be trained, but this was one of the only marsupials who actually posed a ‚Äòthreat‚Äô to colonisation in Tasmania. It was the size of a dog, and of course would start hunting sheep and chickens when their habitats were taken over. Naturally humankind got pissy and paid for everyone to start just opening fire and killing them on sight, which is also what they did to native Tasmanians. When everyone noticed ‚ÄòHey I wonder where all the tigers wentü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚Äô they‚Äôd have a change of heart and have a few of them thrown in cages and shown off as endangered species. Not because they cared about saving them but for the profit. Pretty much, it was a disease like canine distemper that put the existence of Tasmanian tigers in jeprody, but it was human beings that really snuffed them out. The interesting thing being that I don‚Äôt actually think the Tasmanian tigers did that much damage to farm animals to begin with, people were just threatened by the fact this was an animal they couldn‚Äôt control like domestic dogs and stuff. Anyway it would be considered a cryptid given some people really believe there are a few who survived their premature extinction and just live hiding from human beings. It‚Äôs a thing for people to go looking for them sometimes, and there are scientists trying to bring them back who really think they‚Äôve got a shot given how recent their extinction was.

Here‚Äôs the thing about the jackalope, it sort of actually exists. Rabbits are susceptible to a virus called Shope papilloma. This virus causes horrific hard lumps to form out of the rabbits body/face, giving the appearance of horns. The early settlers probably saw rabbits with this condition when they first thought they were seeing jackalopes.

LETS GO LETS FUCKING GO
My Bigfoot like Encounter,  Here in  WV, when I was about 20, I got stalked for the worst 5 miles of my life one night, while walking down a rural, by something that sounded & moved like some kind of feline bigfoot. It was tall with very long arms, covered in jagged dark fur, it moved like a big cat, just on 2 legs &  it screamed 3 times, possibly trying to get me to freeze or turn and run, but it sounded like a mix between the MGM lion at the beginning of movies & the GNARLIEST death metal scream/growl ever, completely inhuman, but human somehow. I barely heard the 1st sound over my shuffling feet, the 2nd time was much louder, which caused me to stop and peer out into the dark field it was coming from and it came the 3rd time loud, clear, and WAY closer like it was running up on me but stopped just outside the range of the roadside light. As calmly as possible retreated to where I was coming from, but was turned away( complicated situation with baby momma) I took a big kitchen knife, (b4 I owned a handgun) The only thing that kept me from sleeping on the stairwell of the building, was the scene in the Howling or some other Werewolf movie where these people get eaten in the stairwell, so I set back out completely terrified. I made a mile back into the road, where the houses thinned out and the road opened up to cornfields, that had luckily been harvested or I wouldn't have had any visibility to protect me, but there were patches of woods staggered down the road on opposite sides. When I get a lil down the road from the last houses for a while & a patch of woods, start to feel a little better. Then I heard gravel shuffle maybe 100 yards behind me a turn to see it, fully silhouetted by the last floodlight on a carport in all its shaggy fur-covered horror crossing the road into the wooded patch opposite side of the road that ran next to me.  and it continued to methodically make it's way through the woods, mostly quietly, but with occasion LOUD branch snappings.  I would only see glimpses occasionally when I caught it changing sides of the road to stay in the tree lines to continue to work after me. I really think after it didn't get the desired effect from screaming, it knew I had prepared myself and was trying to get to where it could take me by surprise( I mean I carried a big kitchen knife in my hand in the full open, so it probably saw that) I completely forgot about the knife in my hand the 1st time I was passed by a car, and tried to wave, what ended up being a Sheriff's deputy down with a blade in my hand but I was completely ignored &  heartlessly left me to my fate .I realized I lost ground to it by stopping to wave at the car and  Luckily, a few more passing cars & their headlights let me gain distance on it while it hid from sight and I double-timed it when in the headlights before returning to defensive mode when they got past. At the 3 1/2 mile mark or so a field full of cattle next to the road completely spazzed out and stampeded in a circle around the field on the opposite side of the road completely spooked unlike anything I'd ever seen in person & then another 1/4 mile later 3 green-lighted EMT SUVs(1st time I'd seen Green emergency lights) popped the hill and flew by me and all signs of the creature were gone along with the feeling of being stalked &  I made it, but 5 other people I knew, or people who told stories to people I knew had similar experiences on the same road.

Funny thing about the dogman: In medieval times, people genuinely believed that people with dog heads were a thing. They were called cynocephali and showed up in a lot of bestiaries and old artwork. They weren't monsters, either: They were literally just humans, wearing clothes and having jobs and stuff, except they had canine heads. Also I think one of them was a Catholic saint, or something like that. Wild stuff.

Quick nitpick, but Thylacine is pronounced with a soft C, so "Thyla-seen" and they were never in New Zealand, only Tasmania and Mainland Australia. NZ actuality never had any native land mammals, aside from bats, because it split off from the Gondwana Land supercontinent before mammals evolved. So they just got birds and some reptiles as the dominant vertebrates there. That's why you get birds like the kiwi, that fill the niche of something like a shrew.

I have a mounted jackelope!
bio student here to deliver my 2 cents on the thylacine and the coelacanth --  thylacine: it's really sad WHY they went extinct - they used to be quite numerous but farmers believed they were what was killing their livestock. thus, they set out to hunt them near extinction HOWEVER it being a marsupial meant it occupied a very specific niche and would be constrained to preying on smaller animals and other marsupials. once word got out, only one thylacine was alive in a zoo. 2 months after being declared protected, it died of negligence because the zookeeper forgot to bring it inside for the night.   coelacanth: coelacanths are meant to be one of if mot THE earliest ancestor to all tetrapods, since its lobe fins had bony structures synonymous to our arm/leg structures (humerus and on/femur and on). they were originally thought to be extinct since the youngest fossil was around 66 ma. in the 1930s, curator Marjorie Courtenay-Latimer found the fish in a wastepile and was determined for it to be looked at but was turned away several times until JLB Smith (another curator, specialty in fishes) from South Africa saw the coelacanth for what it was. funnier is this story from the 1990s - biologist named Mark Erdmann (whose entire career centres on cataloging Indonesian marine life) was on honeymoon in Indonesia and had found coelacanths *also* in refuse piles in these fish markets. he hypothesised another population of coelacanths existing in Raja Ampat in 2018, and lo-and-behold there *sure was.*  anyways, they were found in refuse bins because they don't taste that good ü§∑üèΩ

Regarding Chupacabra, I would like to add that while the name itself was coined by a radio talk show host in the 90's as a joke, the phenomenon actually goes back to the 70's. In a small town out west called Moca there were reported incidents of livestock killed and drained of blood, so much so that it was dubbed  "El Vampiro de Moca" (the vampire of Moca) in the local newspaper.  Furthermore, when the chupacabra popped up again in the 90s, this time in the eastern town of Can√≥vanas, the actual mayor of the town formed an armed posse and led several expeditions into the rainforest in search of the beast. Just a bit of Puerto Rico lore for you all.

Everything you said about the Tassie Tiger was true, but there is a little more to its "cryptid status." Much like the jackalope, it's a bit of a local legend but also an inside joke. It's sort of like everyone pretends to believe that it's not extinct, and shares stories that they don't really believe in themselves, but it's all for a bit of fun.  The thylacine was also well known for walking awkwardly, and having a bit of a hopping run, similar-ish to a kangaroo. When I was younger, my dad and I saw a pair of glowing eyes behind some trees at night, and as they moved, they went up and down. We couldn't see the creature's body, and realistically, it was just a kangaroo, but we liked to say that we had "absolute proof" that the thylacine was still alive.  So it's really just a joke, and a bit of fun to scare tourists, but I still hold out hope that the Tassie Tiger is still out there. The wiki page on the thylacine has a section on sightings I'd recommend checking out. Hope dropbears get mentioned :)

Dogman was underrated and mischaracterized in this video pretty bad IMO... I've heard hundreds of eyewitness encounters for these things and it's not necessarily a man's body, more like a man's torso, with longer arms and clawed hands that go down to the knees and canine legs with hocks. Essentially a werewolf that does not transform or shapeshift, rather a flesh and blood apex predator. Also I feel like the fixation on some random song some guy wrote to characterize the entirety of eyewitness encounters before and after it was written, is a little dishonest. Considering it's a Lycan type creature, werewolf legends go back way further than that guy's song; and considering Dogman is essentially a flesh and blood werewolf that doesn't transform, if it's existence is presumed to be true then it has likely just undergone a name change and recharacterization in lore from shapeshifter/half human, to flesh and blood wolf creature with humanoid traits. Dogman and werewolf sightings and lore are sure to be intertwined throughout history, if modern reports are to be considered seriously, then it's safe to assume that people were seeing the exact same creature centuries ago and just had a different mythos and lore surrounding the sightings at that time period.

I know this is totally out of the blue, but I feel like y'all would appreciate my theory on the Loch Ness Monster.  Nessie is most commonly depicted with a reptilian appearance, owing to its physical similarity to the extinct plesiosaur- its long neck, flippers, and the shape of its body and head all bearing a striking resemblance to the plesiosaurs. While the reported size of Nessie varies from report to report, it's usually described as somewhere from fifteen to twenty feet in length, also very similar to a plesiosaur. As far as I can tell, the largest Nessie has been described as was 50 feet in length. Now, that is longer than any known species of plesiosaur, but certain species of the Elasmosauridae family such as the Albertonectes and Aristonectes have been known to reach nearly 40 feet in length. Additionally, a different marine reptile, an ichthyosaur species known as Shonisaurus popularis, was somewhere between 44 and 49 feet long, and another ichthyosaur, S^. sikenniensis, was a whopping *69 feet* in length, meaning that it's definitely possible for marine reptiles to be 50 feet or more in length. So it is very possible that a 50-foot-long plesiosaur may have existed. Or even that another, different kind of marine reptile such as an ichthyosaur could have developed a similar long-necked profile in a case of convergent evolution. And yes, plesiosaurs and ichthyosaurs definitely lived in the area that would become Great Britain. However, I don't believe that the Loch Ness monster is a marine reptile of any kind. Considering how infrequently it apparently surfaces, there's no way it could be anything that isn't capable of breathing underwater. In other words, it has to be either a fish or amphibian. More specifically, I believe it is most likely an amphibian. You may be asking, "an amphibian of such a large size?? Is that possible??" Possibly. Prionosuchus was a prehistoric amphibian with a strikingly crocodilian-like appearance, including its immense size- nearly twenty feet in length. Now, amphibians larger than Prionosuchus are not currently known to have existed, but I see no reason that they couldn't have. Prionosuchus was an archegosaur, which lived fully aquatic lifestyles despite being capable of breathing on land. While no species of archegosaur have been _known_ to inhabit the area that would become Great Britain, it's not an impossibility, seeing as numerous species of archegosaur can be found throughout other parts of Europe. I don't think it's an impossibility that some archegosaurs could have evolved from a crocodilian body plan into a plesiosaur-esque one, seeing how certain plesiosaurs(known as pliosaurs) themselves had a more crocodilian body plan, such as Kronosaurus. So yes, I think it's very possible that Nessie is, in fact, an amphibian.   ^S. sikenniensis is of debated classification, being either another species of Shonisaurus or a species of a closely related genus, Shastasaurus.

"Champie is a horned serpent".... uh. That kind of... set me off. See, i remember hearing that Thunderbirds, the almost dragon-like storm bringing birds that apparently span across multiple tribes' mythology, are in opposition to two other factions. As they are bringers of sky, fire from above and the rejuvenation of the land they serve counter to entities from under the waters and underground. These aquatic panthers that tend to be tied to mines and the Horned Serpents. The feline former are purported to be the more savage antagonists but the latter being more benign and capable of listening to natives and pleas. .... Now, i'm not weaving any conspiracy here... But I do live in Oklahoma. Oklahoma has its own Eldritch Horror God, Yigg the Father of Serpents. Technically a synthetic god, but regardless, I digress. Snakes, particularly behorned ones... ones with aquatic ties, are an oddly reoccurring figure in american mythology. There is the Serpent Mounds too. What's odd about this is, while i'm often a critic of multiple, spread out reinventing of a myth species (dragons) the very many tribes of who first lived on this soil have every reason to call foul on each other's veracity.  "Horned Serpent" is a little too oddly specific & used to not have some sort of evolution there. I do apologize if I can't cite sources, my memory is spotty at best. The Dogman legend didn't start with the song, dude, oh my God. People have been reporting this creature throughout modern history, and it's always reported as insanely terrifying. There are supposedly seven different types. You really could have researched this a little more. The show Dogman Encounters is on close to its 500th episode of an hour length. People have very detailed, emotional stories that largely line up as far as details. I see lots of people in comments sections reporting to have seen one, and it's always terrifying. And what about Linda Godfrey's work, The Beast of Bray Rd? Highly credible, same creature. People couldn't possibly make this stuff up. The real question is, from where do these creatures come? I have my theory, that's for sure, and with how intelligent they're described as being, it's hard not to speculate on a connection to the Missing 411 cases. There's also evidence that they're a predator of Bigfoot. Who the hell told you the legend began with the song? Don't trust that person; you probably don't know him personally anyway.  And there's WAY more information on Loch Ness Monster than you're aware of. Way more sightings, History Channel documentaries, books, a dead researcher. Watch the History Channel material.  Cryptids are a super serious subject and deserve a lot more scrutiny than this semi-serious take. Loren Coleman is great. Have you read his books? David Weatherly as well, and Ken Gerhard. David Paulides has a long "Bigfoot 101" series on YouTube; it's really good. Bigfoot is fascinating, because the DNA study by Melba Ketchum did show that it's a human-like hominid. This has been covered up. Scott Carpenter wrote a book about it called "Truth Denied," then Scott Carpenter turned up dead recently. Bigfoot also clearly has paranormal, dimension hopping abilities. There's a book on this by Josh Cutchin and Timothy Remer called "Where the Footprints End."  I think the cryptid mystery is a big key to understanding the mystery of our planet and should be looked at really closely and with seriousness. And the bad actors of our world don't want this information known, I can tell you that much.  As far as chupacabra, I think the Puerto Rico creature and the Texas one are just totally different creatures, not sure how they got called the same thing....

Also, the coelacanth is often used as a red herring to support nonsense like man existed with dinosaurs or that dinosaurs still exist today in parts of the world. Proponents claim that since a fish that was alive during the time of dinosaurs, but supposedly went extinct is still alive yet missing from the fossil record that the same logic applies to the ‚Äúliving dinosaur‚Äù theory. The problem is that no such absence from the record exists and has not for some time. It‚Äôs been completely filled in, from the time they supposedly went extinct all the way to modern species with evidence of evolution along the way.

Hi, Dr. Goon, mexican here. An interesting thing about the chupacabras is that, in M√©xico, it's legend wasn't as organic as in PR or even Texas. At the time, we were going trough both the last sever financial crisis and the last threatening guerrilla uprising we've had so far and, keeping traditions, corruption scandals. So the federal government promoted the chupacabras sightings that started making noise just across the border to a level of mass hysteria so the people would focus on something else. They even used our non union mexican equivalent of Fox News to "track down" the path of the chupacabras as it expanded its cattle mutilation from northern M√©xico to the whole country. This makes the chupacabra an existing creature certified by the mexican government and media... So, a lie

Hi, Aussie here. I think the reason why the thylacine is on the iceberg is because although they're formally considered extinct, some people believe that they didn't completely die off and that there are still thylacines alive somewhere in the Tasmanian wilderness. Which makes them similar to more mythic cryptids like bigfoot or nessie.
Iceberg analysis starts at 10:30 thank me later
There have been quite a few reported sightings of Thylacines in Australia since the species was declared extinct. I've seen some photos of what looks like one darting across a rural road, from only a few decades ago. It's possible there are, or were, small, isolated populations of them around South Eastern Australia. If they do still exist, there probably aren't enough of them for the species to survive, so it will be extinct soon if it isn't already. But existence debated means it qualifies and so shouldn't be listed as N/A. Also, they were never in New Zealand. Australia and New Zealand have completely distinct and unrelated ecosystems.  As for Dogmen, that's an old legend long predating the existence of European settlements in North America. Multiple ancient explorers from Europe and the Middle East reported encountering whole communities of them, both in the Himalayan foothills of modern India and also on islands past India, in what was probably South East Asia. There were even essays written by prominent theologians in the Middle Ages debating whether they had souls (as their existence was never confirmed, and doubted by many, they were basically cryptids back then).

Fun fact - well, not so fun, but still: Myths of the jackalope most likely come from sightings of hares and rabbits with the Shope papilloma virus, a papillomavirus that occurs among some animals in the hare family which causes growths resembling horns to develop on or near the animal's head.

You misunderstand - the kr√§ken was first written of a few centuries ago, but tales of it go back over a thousand years among the Norse, Danes, and Svensk. Also, it's not the colossal squid - that's actually a smaller species of large squid that rarely tops 6ft in length. The kr√§ken relates to both the *giant* squid, Archeteuthis Dox (which was first empirically confirmed on-film in the early 2000s, in the deep ocean off Japan) and the giant octopus better known as the lusca, as both were basically indistinguishable to the observing seamen a milennium ago. The thylacine (thigh-la-seen) is not extinct. They've been sighted in the wild the past 20 years. He's called *Champ,* not "champie". What are you, a filthy lobsterback? Leeds' 13th child was born hideously deformed and was discarded in the forest as being "cursed by the devil". The story of it transforming into a thestral arose from gossip in town during the aftermath - "the story grows in the telling", remember? Well it was getting told and embellished a lot for a couple months, because 18th century villagers had nothing better to do in their off hours. Never believe tales from superstitious people (aka heretics).

Regarding Jackalopes: they actually are real, in a sense. Not as a distinct species, but there‚Äôs a known leporid infection called the Shope papilloma virus which causes keratinous tumors resembling horns to grow from hares‚Äô heads. It‚Äôs almost certainly the source of the original jackalope legend that the Herrick brothers built on.   So the Jackalope is less a cryptid, and more the name for an animal with a specific condition. Kind of like how a black panther is just a melanistic jaguar.  Edit: Removed information I got wrong.

i'm lowkey obsessed with the thylacine. these are so so SO incredibly beautiful and interesting animals, and while that goes for all animals, extinct and alive, the story of their extinction is just so profoundly tragic and just "humans are shitballs" in a nutshell.  they were hunted mercilessly because sheep farmers thought of them as these bloodthirsty beasts that would come to kill their sheep; basically the same story as with wolves, with the exception that one, wolves were far spread enough to survive humanity's manic outburst of dominating nature, and two, it was later found that thylacines were too small and had too weak jaws to wrestle and kill a whole ass sheep. so they were genocided because of people's distaste for any living being that they perceived as an inconvenience. the tragedy doesn't stop there though. the last two specimens of thylacines were kept in a zoo, and you know how zoos used to be so much worse. their pen was a small concrete area with a chainlink fence. there are videos where visitors are provoking them, bringing dogs along to the fence, hitting the fence and just in general severely and VISIBLY stressing the two out FOR FUN. the female eventually died, leaving the male alone for years in this hellhole, until he died, but not of old age, but very likely due to exposure after being locked out of the shelter during a cold night, so he froze to death. the last member of a whole species died because someone couldn't give a shit. also fun fact, from what info we still have today, the female was never given a name and was just "the male's partner". the male was referred to as Benjamin.  really, humans didn't just hunt them to extinction, they tortured them to extinction. and as much as i wish this wonderful species survived this ordeal somehow, i doubt it.

The Jersey Devil scared me so bad as a kid, mainly because there was this island level from Poptropica, an online adventure game (for those who are unfamiliar). There was an island (each island had a different story/theme) that was all about Cryptids. It had the basics like Bigfoot, Nessie, and the Chupacabra. Then, it had you go to New Jersey to find proof of the Jersey Devil. It had you wander through the woods at night until you found an old abandoned house. You walked through the house, found nothing, but as you were leaving, a figure of the Jersey Devil staring at you through the window before you followed it outside and it flew off. All this to say that this cartoony picture of the Jersey Devil scared the shit out of child me, as well as many others my age üòÇ. It was my first introduction into cryptozoology and the Jersey Devil, and now, like 10+ years later, I still remember it fondly

The Thylacine was not found in New Zealand but rather in Papua New Guinea(new Zealand has no native mammals other than bats).  Additionally, the reason it's a Cryptid is not because it went extinct and is a cool reminder of what used to exist, it's because there are a lot of people that still think it does exist and there are people and organisations that are still looking for them.

10 minute intro lol
Jackalope-like cryptids are very widespread throughout Europe, mainly in the Germanic region though.  In my area we have the Rasselbock which are rabbits with roe deer horns, which allegedly live in the  forested mountains of Thuringia.   In Bavaria they have the Wolpertinger which is a rabbit with deer antlers, fangs and pheasant or duck wings. It allegedly lives in the alpine forests in Southern Bavaria and Austria. In Austria they're known as Raurakl.  Further to the west a similar creature called the Dilldapp exists around the Swiss German border area.  In Sweden they have the Skvader which is a rabbit with wood grouse wings.  Another interesting, but more jokingly talked about cryptic from my tegion is the Hanghuhn. It's name comes from the word "Hang" (hillside, slope) and "Huhn" (chicken) and it is a chicken with 2 differently long legs because it's standing on the hillsides of the Thuringian Forest all day.
Lock Ness monster is cool because of its simplicity. It invokes a sense of wonder. It doesn‚Äôt need to be more complicated and beats out most of the boring-ass tryhards on this list.

Scottish biologist here  "Lake Loch Ness". It's just Loch Ness. It's a loch and this one is called Loch Ness  Thyalcines (pronounced thigh-la-seen) are on the iceberg because there are still claims of sightings and their recent range includes Australia and Papua New Guinea, which both have extremely remote locations with very low human populations. If any thylacines are still out there, it's possible they're in a Papuan forest or the middle of Australia and supposed sightings do exist  The thylacine was not native to New Zealand. You might be thinking of Tasmania, which is where it gets its common name: Tasmanian Tiger (not to be confused with the extant Tasmanian Devil)

Interestingly enough, the jackalope myth probably originated from seeing rabbits suffering from shope papillomavirus, or a type of bad warts that a rabbit can get that will grow into large growths from their heads- I've seen rabbits that appear to have "horns" because of this common disease. Most likely the jackalope started with someone talking about one of these afflicted rabbits and grew from there!

I have a skunk ape theory, and I wonder if it has been explored before.  Have you ever farted in the shower, and noticed that it smells worse than a fart under normal circumstances? (I promise I‚Äôm going somewhere with this).  It‚Äôs because the humidity in the shower actually increases the ease with which scent travels, which is arguably also why in tropical areas scents and tastes (as a biproduct of the olfactory senses) seems so dialled up.   What if the skunk ape and Bigfoot are the same, smelly creature, but because the Everglades are notoriously hot and humid, the smell is both intensified because they are living in the heat, sweating more, and also the scent travels stronger through the humid air?  I also think that this theory increases the likelihood of both creatures‚Äô existence, as this is a genuine scientific phenomenon we know about, that is well proven and if citizens of both areas of the country saw something similar with this being the primary distinction, they wouldn‚Äôt necessarily know why. hey wendigoon, as someone who's lived in northern michigan my entire life, (and also grew up terrified of the dog man) i wanted to shed some light on why he's so popular. it isn't just that it's a spooky design.  first, the dog man is only active every 7th year of a decade. second, he never, ever directly kills someone. all the references in the song of people/animals dying because it literally scares them to death. the appearance of the dog man is so blood curdlingly unnatural that it can literally make your heart stop. it's the idea that despite michigan's beautiful landscape, you can never really let your guard down or forget the unforgiving nature of... well, nature.

I thinkt the Jackalope myth started when people saw jackrabbits that were affected by the papilloma-virus, which causes horn-like tumors to grow out of their ears, head or bodies. We have a similar cryptid here in Austria/Germany, called 'Raurackl' or 'Wolpertinger'. Basically the same thing as a Jackalope but people not only put horns on a rabbit but wings or duckfeet or other parts of other animals, there are weird creations out there üòÖ

Video starts at 10:25
Somehow I thought my local cryptid, the bray road beast, would make it on tier 1. I'm not surprised it didn't though because it's a little generic werewolf story. What's interesting about the area there in South Eastern WI is that there's a cryptid everyone knows about, but no one is supposed to talk about it. It's a cognito hazard because while you're not allowed to talk about it out loud, it's almost dangerous to think about it. You can "summon it" with speech and it'll find you in the woods and stalk you like prey. Freaked us out as kids walking home in the dark because you'd hear things move in the trees and couldn't stop thinking about this monster that was chasing you. I'd think it was an entirely made up story if not for older generations of people confirming the legends of it. We only ever felt safe to talk about it after moving a 1000 miles away lol. The only name I ever heard it called was "the white thing" and I always imagined it as a yeti, but it kind of overlaps with the local werewolf. I have from time to time tried to look it up online, but as befits a local legend, there is no info. If I didn't know better I'd say it's a wendigo, but there was no stench when as kids we thought it was chasing us in the dark. Just beastial growls and snarling.

Also worth noting about the Jersey Devil was that the Mother Leeds from the story was likely the real life Debora Leeds (maiden name Smith), the wife of Japheth Leeds with whom she had 12 living children (named in Japheth's Will).  Japheth and his brother Titan Leeds both died young, right in the middle of a public feud with Benjamin Franklin, which also coincided with the year typically attributed to the birth of the Jersey Devil.  Titan was a business competitor of Franklin who capitalized on the unpopularity of the Leeds family to promote his own business interest. The patriarch Daniel Leeds previously was accused of "being a devil" and a "harbinger of satan" by the quaker majority, who took issue with his staunch support of the British government.   So yeah... a lot of the Jersey / Leeds Devil legend comes from a spat with a founding father, which I find amusing

Hello, Tasmanian here! While not your traditional cryptid, Some people believe that the Thylacine (or Tasmanian Tiger) never went extinct and we just haven't had proof of seeing one in 90+ years. People post videos and photos claiming to site the Tasmanian Tiger, all 'disproven' so far. We have hunters like you see in America for Bigfoot, and that's probably why it's on the list. We have some of the most rugged and remote bushland in the Australia, and it would not be surprising if there was a small population on the Southwest Coast. Another fun fact! They are actively trying to resurrect the species and release it back into the wild.  Also it's pronounced Thigh-la-seen, no 'k' sound. Thank you for listening to my TAS Talk. Tasmanian away!

As a northern Michigan dude who's lived and worked and been in and out of Wexford county my whole life, I didn't think anything of it when you mentioned it because it's common vernacular here. I absolutely love cryptids and cryptozoology so this is a fantastic video for me!! But I just wanted to say - the thylacine (while an awesome creature) wasn't native to New Zealand, it was an endemic Australian species. We here in Kiwiland don't really have much in the way of native mammals except for bats, it's mostly birds and reptiles!

I'm just hoping giants are on the iceberg.
So I noticed the information on the Thylacine was pretty slim so I, as an Australian, felt it was my duty to fill the gaps.  The Thylacine (pronounced thigh-la-seen) is a now extinct carnivorous marsupial which was sometimes known as the Tasmanian Tiger. The animal went extinct due to bounty hunting due to their threat to livestock. The last of the Thylacine died in Hobart Zoo in 1936, though despite this, people still report sightings to this day. Not just in Tasmania but on the mainland of Australia as well.   I have a feeling that these Thylacine sightings are people spotting large feral cats or mistakenly seeing and misidentifying a dingo, but I would love to believe that the Thylacine is still out there.

marine cryptids like the lochness monster, sea serpents, kraken, etc are always so fascinating to me because they can often be linked to species we've discovered. the legend of sea serpents may come from oarfish, who frequently linger at the surface of the water when they're sick or dying, and the kraken can be linked to colossal squids. my favourite explanation for the lochness monster is that it might just be a whale penis, which is incredibly funny to think about.

Fun fact: The second Chupacabra sighting was at my old neighbours house in PR back in the 90s. My elderly neighbour had gone outside to check on her goats and she saw what she described as a "very, very ugly dog" biting and chewing on her goats and she scared it away with a broom. The next day my uncle went to scope out the place, but he didn't find anything but some blood not too far off from the goats.  That place where the Chupacabra was seen was my favourite place to play when I was a little kid and NO ONE told me.

The thylacine is on the iceberg because there have been sightings of it long after it's supposed extinction in 1936. Just this summer there was a scientific study that gave support to for the thylacine surviving to the 2000s and even possibly (though unlikely) to today in remote parts of Tasmania. There are also thylacine reports in the island of New Guinea in recent years. Thylacine is the "animal that is supposed to be extinct but people still see it" type of cryptid.

Is the chupacabra is one of the saddest things for me.  When I lived in Texas (95-97) it was this kind of lizard-man seahorse looking thing with fangs and needle sharp stones on its back and claws and wings. It was scary enough for us that we didn't want to go into the woods after dark. Like literally, there was this little shortcut from one area to the other, and it was only maybe two hundred meters through the woods, and literally nobody would go through there after dark without a gun and friends.    I had to ride through it one day and my buddy and I tore ass through the area so we didn't have to be there long.  Literally pitch black. And we were riding our bikes as fast as we possibly could through the woods. Probably could have killed ourselves pretty easily l o l. And then a few years later, I see some bullshit claim that the true bicabre is this dumb looking dog thing. I lost all respect for mythmaking abilities of the local people after that.  The original was tied to aliens and cattle mutilation. Among other things. But then suddenly it was just some dumb diseased dog. So disappointing. It was very scary though when it was still the monster thing.

I'd like to add some stuff about the dogman because, while I don't know about the disk jockey, I do know some stuff about medieval mythology. Judging by the descriptor, the dog man is a creature of myth called a cynocephali, a race of dog headed humans. The lore behind them is fascinating and they're seen in several cultures. There's even a saint that's one! I'd look into it if I were you because they are really interesting creatures and much cooler than some dudes story and the modern sightings.

Just as a heads up 12:18 there's no point in saying 'lake' loch ness because Loch is already the Scots Gaelic (not to be confused with Irish Gaelic because their equivalent word is 'lough') word for lake. So if it's a lake in Scotland, it's a loch.

I grew up in Wyoming (specifically Douglas, the hometown of the Jackalope) and the jackalope means so much to me personally. The original jackalope mount was put on display in the LaBonte hotel but it was stolen years and years ago, they never caught the guy.  Other fun 'facts' include: - the current hunting season for them is only June 31st between midnight and 2am - their milk is a powerful, sought-after aphrodisiac - it's illegal to bait them with whiskey (a favorite of theirs) - they can mimic human voices, mostly as self defense  you can still get hunting licenses for them at the Douglas visitor's center. there are also multiple 10+ foot tall statues of jackalopes around town

I had anxiety issues in high school when I was required to give presentations in drama class.  To counter this issue I found if I talk about things that I found interesting, and felt like I was well informed about the subject, I did better.  I went for the shock and awe presentations which included unusual sky fall, spontaneous human combustion, and some other odd subjects I can't remember.  Finally the teacher took me aside after class one day and asked me to do something that wasn't off.  At that point I did a presentation on Regiment 51, the all African American regiment that fought in the Civil War.  That was a fun subject to cover in rural southern Tennessee in the 90s back when we still very much had racism.  I grew up and became an archaeologist that is still very much interested in the paranormal.  I laughed when you mentioned your school research.
I love when you do icebergs!!!üòä
If you think about it, the possibility for a kraken to be real is not as unlikely as many of the other criptids. We have solid evidence of leviathans like the megalodon, but the thing about a kraken is that it would be almost impossible to fossilize because of its soft body with no bones. It could be possible that a squid species larger than the giant squid could have been alive during the Viking era. Or of course it could have just been giant squids being blown out of proportions which is probably the case

The yeti is a huge orangutan that started eating bamboo. Orangutans usually eat fruit which controls their size because food is scarce unlike bamboo which is everywhere. so they grew to unporportionate heights because of their new found food source. there were huge bones found in stores around the area in the 19th century by a scientist. These ‚Äúdragon bones‚Äù as they put it was to solve erectile disfunction and hypothetically you would crush them up. Internet and education mean nothing to ignorant people. I live on lake superior, and a lot of my friends who work in tourist industries have made jokes to tourists about whale watching in the lake. Yes, it is the largest lake in the world at 31,700 square miles, and up to 1,332 feet deep, it has the volume to house a whale, but it's fresh water. Yet tourists will happily believe there are whales, sharks, and dolphins in the lake. Not only on the word of local jokesters, but I have met people in other states who literally just assume those creatures live there without ever having visited or researched the lake. The biggest things in there are lake sturgeon, which can grow to a hefty 150+ lbs, but it's no whale obviously lol.

Ooooo fun! A little help on the Goblin Universe, since thats lower and really weird.   Last Podcast on the Left did a real good breakdown of it, so that would be a good starting point! But basically what the goblin universe is, is more of a metaphor than anything tangible. Basically all supernatural and unexplainer phenomena, from ghosts to aliens and cryptids, are all the same types of entities from the same realm. Entities that peer through the veil of reality will take on the forms that we have either built up subconsiously or have belief structures in. They are masks that they wear, rather than their actual nature. So basically all strangeness comes from the same source, the "goblin universe" (a name the writer gave just to note a fantastical nature) and take on the forms we could best possibly comprhend them in.   All this too came out after the original writers death. The goblin universe was a pet theory of his that he was frankly embarrassed about. But i suppose his friends throught he was on to something
It‚Äôs honestly crazy how some people will swear by something and not have any evidence and go off what someone they know or don‚Äôt know says. I like the stories, but some people are stupid.

The pouch tiger may actually still be alive, though that's a maybe. Apparently on New Guinea there are quite recent reported sightings of them and due to the low human population and dense forests there's a chance that they've survived there, we just haven't found them yet. There's also a project trying to bring back the Australian (I think) pouch tiger since they have the entire genome sequenced. I don't know how they're doing that but apparently they are. The pouch tiger is a carnivore, hence why "tiger" is in it's name. I don't remember what they're actually called so I just call them pouch tigers.  Also that one pic of champie is legit a whale dong.

Small correction. Its not "Lake Loch Ness", its just "Loch Ness". Loch means lake. The English took the word Loch from the Scottish and over time it changed to Lake. Saying "Lake Loch" is like saying "The Los" for any Spanish name.  Edit: If you're curious, before borrowing the word Loch and changing it to Lake, the English used the term Pond. Nowhere days Ponds are small bodies of fresh water and Lakes are large bodies of fresh water, but before that all bodies of fresh water (expect flowing forms like rivers or streams) were ponds in English.

Hot Take: Mountain Monsters is better than finding Bigfoot
Happy to see this come up and looking forward to watching it go deeper, but I have to disagree about placement of the Thylacine. Yes, it was a real animal, but sightings of the animal still persist to this day, long after it should have been extinct in the wild. Nessie, Champie and others are often theorized to be some kind of extant species of aquatic dinosaur that somehow survived, but the Thylacine's extinction date is recent enough where it could be a more plausible example of an extinct species somehow surviving, and that always seemed cool to me.

Michigander here. Allegedly, according to tales from where i was raised at least, there had always been dogman sightings. They went more or less unreported since locals didn't think anyone would believe their stories.   The disc jockey created his song as a joke to try and scare listeners, but was surprised when people started to call in to tell stories of their sightings. It was less that it didn't exist up until that point, but that he accidently gave people an outlet to discuss things they otherwise would have never talked about.

im creek seminole, we were camping at my grandparents old camp with no ac so we just kept the windows open and i was 14 and i could never sleep at that camp because i share my bed with mice late into the evening around 1:00 am i was watching the moon through the window when i was hit with a horrible smell, my parents and my grandparents have found big footprints around the camp before so i was familiar with skunk ape already, i sat up to look out the window kinda hopein it was an actual skunk when i saw the tall bitch slowly taking long steps between my window and the old distill shed going towards our fire and picnic table he was sniffing the air and much taller then a man but not quite 7ft id say 6‚Äô10 i was 5‚Äô10 at the time i stayed as quiet as possible at first because i knew this was a once in a lifetime experience but when he reached the picnic table and looked it over he turned and headed back towards the tree line i‚Äôve always heard he had red eyes but he wouldn‚Äôt look my way so i could confirm thats when i nocked one time loudly on the corner of the window and he turned with his whole torso and shoulder to look at i know in my heart he saw me but he didnt have glowing red eyes but they reflected light like gators if you spot light them or a panther they just reflected the light from the moon in a hazy greenish yellowish hue, put my and up not to wave but like how you would greet another native in hand talk and it didn‚Äôt respond it just froze and stared then without breaking contact he slowly took 4 more steps almost in a fox walk to the tree line once the shadow of the trees covered him he finally broke contact and waded into the waters of the swamp and disappeared he was so silent it was incredible but the smell was horrible it somewhere in between wet dog skunk and marijuana, theres woods here in florida where they filmed an old tarzan movie and they released all the monkeys into the woods and ive seen them and we have pictures of my Howdy, brother. Amazing video, as always! I must point out, though, The Michigan Dogman has been sighted as far back as 1897, give or take. It only seems like people started reporting sightings and encounters after the dj Steve Cook wrote the song because they didn't feel crazy anymore and felt comfortable enough in the belief that they were not alone. I know many people who have had encounters and sightings of Dogman and Bigfoot. We've been so desensitized to stuff like that though through TV, film, and video games. There is absolutely no way in hell a person can change into an animal or even go through just a slight shift in bone structure a few times a year without death immediately after, but follow me on this...  a wolf, coywolf/ coydog, coyote, or even a pack of stray dogs, over time evolve or in a faster method living so close to mankind, could learn to adapt and catch different prey. They already hu t flightless birds, why not evolve enough to be able to run fast enough to stand on its hind legs to jump higher and have a better chance of catching said prey? Partridge, ducks, geese, corvids the sky is the limit.. no pun intended. Or even just be able to stand on the hind legs to see over tall grass, find deer better in farm fields? I mean, I'm prolly just lit up like a dashboard, but seems like legit reasoning lmfao

For the blind, she is their vision. For the deaf, she is their music. For the mute, she is their voice. For the anosmiac, she is their aroma. For the numb, she is their feeling. For the atrophied, she is their muscle. For the starved, she is their sustenance. For the thirsty, she is their water. For the exhausted, she is their energy. The Thylocine -  never in new Zealand . Nor mainland Australia , or further north .  Found only in Tasmania -  last one died early last century .   Please get your facts right , as new Zealand biggest predator , was Hasts Eagle , which hunted Moa , some of which were bigger than an Ostrich , which the Eagle was capable of flying off with .
I think you undersold dogmen a bit, they've been around a lot longer than the DJ's song. For example, over in Estonia, we have 2 names for them, koerakoonlased and peninuki. It is believed that our legends came from Ivan the Terrible's special guard oprichniki, who would ride around terrorising and torturing our people, trying to "sniff" out enemies of the tsar during the Livonian war in 1565-1572.   To symbolise said sniffing, they would carry a decapitated head of a dog attached to the saddle of their horse. Unfortunately they didn't preserve the heads in any way, so they would need a constant supply of freshly decapitated dog heads. As you can probably guess, this sort of thing will launch a legend pretty speedily.   This is just one more obscure example almost 500 years ago, but there's a LOT of dog headed man legends from many different cultures all the way to Ancient Greece and Egypt. If anyone's interested in looking up more, cynocephaly (dog-head) is a pretty effective search term.   Ofc its understandable that covering things can't be very in depth for something this size. Just a little lore drop from my neck of the woods I wanted to share. Super excited for the whole series!!

I'm not familiar with the layout of the tier lists; what cryptid goes on what tier list? My point is that I'm not sure if you've left some out that should be in tier 1; they aren't 'left out' they are just in amount tier category?  What defines the category of tiers? Is it notoriety or popularity and then things become more obscure as you ripple outwards? Is it based on believability or likeliness to be an actual create vs myth/urban legend? If I'm aware of the selection criteria I can preemptively note where a cryptid may have been forgotten? Sometimes these are like nested aliases under the main category of a cryptid and not necessarily seperate new individual cryptids.... Like for instance I can't accuse you of forgetting the Australian version of the Bigfoot known as the Yowie? If Yowie is it's own classification of bigfoot, then not including it is as good as forgetting it? But if we collectively normalise the categorisation to begin with it would have Bigfoot being like kingdom name and then sub species to identify selective geographical ranges example Bigfootous Americani is likewise Bigfootous Yowie Australis or Bigfootous Yeti Himalamini  But getting to my point......... How could you possibly forget the Rake? This is by far the most terrifying and potentially real cryptid out of any of them? Because most footage claims to be of it are usually between a person and this what can only be described as the most brutal and violent long armed quadpedal humanoid grey alien being with a gate comparable to a cheetah......? Its also one of these creatures that isn't timid if spooked, in fact if it sees you from a distance it will actively seek to track you down? It's not like most creatures that will hide and hope you didn't see it? Or run away from you but only fight if cornered..........whoa back right up a second, this thing wants to destroy you the moment it sees you! Its all out ballastic rage makes it's unpredictability so high that there is no strategy for defeating it? All you can hope is that death comes to you swiftly so that you aren't suffering when you are attacked.  By far the most truely terrifying cryptid in existence in my opinion? And all accounts, claims or footage seem to show a uniform pattern of behaviour.... Comparing recorded footage from France  to recorded footage of America shows consistent behavior; this makes the notion of this potentially being authentic rather high! Footage from 10 years ago of the rake looks the same as recent footage of the rake?  The fact that there are so many recordings all from different people from all over the world all recording the same looking creature behaving same as has been recorded before. 100% same amounts and claims. This has to be a real creature and it's terrifying!

About the Jackalope: In Germany, specifically Bavaria, we have a similar creature called a "Wolpertinger/ Wolperdinger". Its a combination of different animals mostly a rabbit with antlers and duck wings, and sometimes even fangs. But they're described as nonaggressive.

so when it comes to the jackelope, i believe it may have an origin in the southern german "Wolpertinger" which is effectively an amalgamation of various animals, very often horned, the exact animal may differ but its most often rabbits, with various features, which may be sharp teeth, fish tails, duck feet, wings, anything the mind could come up with. the creation of taxidermy wolpertinger dates to the 19th century, the exact age of the myth and its origin is unclear but given the broad range of local variations, especially in name and the habit of the german language to usually change very little over time, it is very likely an old myth

"Bigfoot is so popular that there's no consistency to the story anymore" That's been the case from the beginning though? native folklore regarding the wild/hairy/giant men of the forrests also varied widely from tribe to tribe, some depicted them as dangerous monsters to be feared and avoided and while others might go so far as to name them "the husband of mother earth/nature", and of course others just treated them as fairly neutral entitiesto be respected because they were poweful and had territory you shouldn't vilolate unless you want trouble with them, and so on.  It's almost like this is a wild animal that could do any and all these things in the eyes of humanity and says just as much about those humans as it does the creature itself.  Edit: the famous Myakka Ape photos are a bit more complicated then just "it was a Ripley's Believe It Or Not display" since no such display matching the creature pictured has ever been proven to have existed(with the example shown to try and prove such a thing shows a radically different looking Bigfoot in completely different foliage), so who knows what it was a photo of, could still be a hoax, but it's probably not from a Ripley's display

In Germany we have a cryptid very similar to the Jackalope called Wolpertinger. Its a rabbit with antlers, wings and pointy teeth. The origins are unknown but references go back to the early 18th century or even older. Apart from Wolpertinger it has a bunch of other names, depending on the region.

Chupacabra always freaked me put when I was a kid ~2005 because all the cryptid books I read made it look like a freaky alien. The dog version doesn‚Äôt bother me as much
Personally I like splitting cryptids into 2 categories. 1 is the clear urban legend supernatural esoteric bs like ghosts, vampires, alien hybrids etc. 2 is what could be an actual animal. We know that we only know around 10-15% of existing  animal species (even if most of those would be insects and deep sea creatures). Many many now documented animals were considered myths before we could find a specimen (in fact we have ones that have only been confirmed to exist by one or two remains that we've found, not to mention that we wipe species from existence every year). This is legitimate zoological research. Now, there is obvious overlap - before we find an animal we usually hear about it from the stories of the locals and try to separate fiction from fact. Still, there are legends that are clearly just kept alive by hype, and fictional mythology has taken the reins from any real-world inspiration. Elements that have a clear source in books and popular media can be separated from documented real events.

You actually made a pretty vital mistake with the thylacine there. As an Australian I can attest that the animal has attained mythical status over the last few decades as people have claimed to see late-surviving Tasmanian tigers still roaming the bush. It‚Äôs become something of a legend over here. It‚Äôs not usually taken seriously, BUT if people reporting sightings of a late-surviving plesiosaur (Nessie) counts as a cryptid, I would argue that people doing the same for a late-surviving marsupial should count as one too. Culturally, thylacine sightings over here are treated about the same as any cryptid/paranormal report.

Video starts at 9:50 guys
17:21 Best instance of the Kraken happens to be an attack on the U.S. naval Frigate the USS Stein when a giant squid of unknown size attacked and destroyed the ships undersea radar dome. The ship was rocked by the impact and saw its speed decline until the propellers of the ship thunked a few times and the creature departed. Based on the tooth embedded in the vessels radar dome the Squid would have had to have been between 100-165ft; making it the largest squid ever recorded. Tooth is now in a museum, and ironically despite the massive size of the creature, most sailors had not noticed the incident took place till after the ship was in dry dock.

The mention of the "dogman" makes me hope you'll mention the "cynocephali" or "dog heads." They were like a cryptid of the ancient world, and while they were kind of plain in their appearance, just men with dogs' heads, they were interesting in that they sparked a lot of philosophical and theological discussions. Also, there's literally a saint who was thought to be a cynocephalus, Saint Christopher.

Love your content, but just to let you know as an Aussie it's  pronounced Thigh-la-seen (Thylacine) . Thanks for having it included and thank you for your content. But I just wanted to let you know how it's pronounced from where it's from. It's also debated on if it's still alive or not also having people state there was sitings years after it being reported extinct. Also there was unknown paw prints found in the forest of Tassie that were sent off and identified as thylacine paw prints. People think they are currently living in a hard to get to part of Tassie forrest. And thus explains the sittings and why people can't just find them easy. If this all makes sense. Just some stuff I heard from my partner who grew up in Tassie.

Just to clarify with the Thylacine (pronouced thigh-la-seen btw), the reason it gets mentioned in the cryptid world is because they were hunted into extinction in Tasmania, however due to the dense and mountainous wilderness people claim they are still out in the wild. There have been rumours of wild sightings in Tasmania for decades, but they've never been proven

dog cop be like:
My dad is from Jersey and he told me the story of the Jersey Devil on a long car ride and it scared me STRAIGHT. I had been afraid of the dark my entire life, even during my first years of college, and I could never sleep without a night light or something. Part of the story my dad told me involved the jersey devil stamping out a campfire and breaking the headlights while chasing a car because he hated the light. TRUST i went to bed in pitch darkness for a week and was never afraid of the dark like i used to be.
I'm sure someone has already mentioned this but the reason the Thylacine would have been on here would also be that a *lot* of Australians (specifically Tasmanians) think that the thylacine still exists- about 40% of Tasmania is national forest land, and a significant portion of that sees very little foot traffic, so theres quite a bit of land that the thylacine could still live on! Speak to just about anyone who hikes there, and they'll tell you that they believe the thylacine is still alive

The Tasmanian Tiger (Thylacine) is actually considered a cryptid due to a number of supposed sightings and belief by some that they are still alive. Not fitting the more mystical side of cryptozoology of things like Sasquatch or Mothman, but still a cryptic by its definition.

Very sorry to do this, but the jackelope cryptid is based on a much sadder real life thing called Shope papilloma virus. It's a disease that causes rabbits to grow big masses that resemble horns. It's highly contagious and can be passed between rabbits just by a person handling a rabbit with the disease and then handling another rabbit.   Likely someone saw a rabbit suffering from this disease, told people about it, and that then became the more wholesome story you told.   Good news: jackelopes are real   Bad news: they are just very sick rabbits :(

My favorite cryptid is actually a local goat man. It was explained within a week of discovery, but a fun story all the same   A local hiker saw a herd of mountain goats, but noticed that one looked weirdly human shaped. They snapped a picture and sent it to the newspaper. I saw it at the time and was delighted and intrigued. There was just... a goatman. Right there in the news.   A week later there was an update. The goat man was a wildlife photographer who was apparently trying to get closer shots of the mountain goats by dressing up to blend in. He contacted the newspaper after seeing the photo.    Honestly, a man dressing up as a goat to photograph goats feels like cryptid behavior on its own.
I‚Äôm super excited for this series! And I just got my hoodie today!
I had an anthropology prof once and we were going over the early hominids, and the conversation sort of veered into Bigfoot. He then started a story by telling us that what he was saying was coming from him as a person, not as an anthropology professor. He then very seriously told us a story about how he had seen Bigfoot crossing a river in Western Washington, and that it had changed his perspective forever on anthropology. Then he went right back to lecturing - super weird and interesting guy but I still wonder about it to this day.

So the Jackalope has the same grounding in reality that the Unicorn does. The name of the disease escapes me, but there is a zoological disease that causes animals to grow rough horn-like appendages on various points on the body. If one of these protrusions happened to grown on a rabbit's head (or a horse's head), it would most certainly look like a Jackalope (Unicorn) to someone who didn't know any better. I think the disease is the Shope's Virus, but im not sure.

Technically, anything supernatural is NOT a cryptid. Cryptids are hidden animals, so if a creature is not a biological animal that is at least theoretically part of the fossil record, it's just a supernatural entity from folklore, not a cryptid.

Fun fact about the Loch Ness Monster: A team of people were scanning the lake to try and find it, and they found what appeared to be exactly the monster laying on the bottom of the lake. However, it ended up being a massive monster prop from an old Sherlock Holmes movie that had been filmed there.

I would have agreed with you on the whole thing with the Loch Ness monster I thought he was really overrated, but I learned when I went to Ireland, and I studied the old church hero of Saint Columba. I learned that there‚Äôs a story dating all the way back to the time of Saint Columba regarding a group of Druids, dragging a dead body out of Loch Ness that was mangled and had been half eaten when Saint Columba asked what happened to the man. They said that there was a creature in the lake. He dismissed this and crossed the lake, saying that God would protect him when all the sudden, a creature rose from the lake and tried to devour him, it is said That he performed a cruciform with his hands and rebuke the creature and the creature sunk back into the lake. This miracle allowed Saint Columba to minister the gospel to the Scottish natives because they saw his power.

I've been to the International Cryptozoology Museum. It's small but full of so many interesting things. What I love is they include real animals that were once considered crytpids/extinct, and they also note when something is a known hoax. I loved the map of Maine that shows various types of sightings. In my area they had large cat sightings listed. Which is funny because my dad himself has seen a large cat that "doesn't exist" in this area. I was also told by my step father that someone owned a lion decades ago and it had escaped and been on the loose for a while before they caught it. Which seems so outlandish until you watch something like Tiger King and realize that people illegally owning big cats is just a fact of life apparently! Looking forward to this iceberg. ü•Ç

This one had the antlers and it had the rabbit body, but it had back legs similar to a rooster. It was in our garage and it was well-lit. Thank you for mentioning the coast Salish origins of Sasquatch! I live by the Salish sea (the sea of which the coast Salish tribes are native to) and it‚Äôs pretty awesome to live in the origin grounds for the most famous cryptid of all time. (Yes, there is Bigfoot/Sasquatch art and merch EVERYWHERE here)
I do think Mothman is honestly the face of cryptozoology, at least in the west. It's the classic architypical mythological monster, but created in the modern day with modern ideas of what animals and people are like.  It really is just straight up a modern Myth, no nagging little asterisks or qualifiers, its even treated like the myths of old too, at least in our modern renditions of those traditions (statues of metal instead of sculptures of clay, for example).   And I actually do agree the skunk ape is scarier then Bigfoot, because with Bigfoot's mythos, theres an implied intelligence there, an implied intent. If Bigfoot comes to kill you, the mythos it's your fault. The skunk ape is just a wild, scared animal. And when a scared animal is cornered, intentionally or not, it'll do anything to survive.

22:30 No what you‚Äôre saying makes perfect sense. Horror is built on the relationship between your mind and the environment. A creature is only as scary as the environment they‚Äôre in, but can also meld into and add to the environment, and so in a way can make the horror exponentially more effective. Thus the Everglades adding to the ape and making him more threatening is absolutely understandable, as it builds on a key facet of horror that honestly too much of the genre misses out on.

Video starts at 10:00
The reason the Thylacine would be on the list is to do with what happened after the last known animal went extinct in 1936. Ever since there have been regular supposed sightings of the animal all over Tasmania, with searches being undertaken by scientists, hunters, and farmers, and with huge amounts of money being offered by various people for proof of its continued existence. Hence the animal has transitioned from being a real thing into being more of a cryptid. There's a similar legend where I was raised in Gippsland of black panthers, which were either escaped from a circus or were mascots for the US Army when they were here in WW2, depending who you ask. Every few years a farmer produces a blurry photo of a large black cat and claims he saw the panther.
Have you watched "The Mothman Prophecies" starring Richard Gere? Interesting movie.  Also, if you haven't read "The Wendigo" by Algernon Blackwood, I highly recommend it.
