Is Santa a cryptid
wah
Thylacine is a cryptid. Cryptozoology is the study of creatures as of yet unknown or not yet confirmed to exist by science, but that does include species that once definitely existed and may continue to exist in some small, remote population. In contrast to things that didn't and don't exist (wendigos, skinwalkers and other mystical mumbo-jumbo) it's a bonafide, certified cryptid.
Little do you know Wendigoon is actually a time traveler and is responsible for the sinking of the Titanic.

honestly I think you did kraken really dirty putting it in B tier. personally I think that's solid S material  the fact there's evidence of things similar to it alone makes it cool enough for at least something higher than B. it opens up the floodgates for all kinds of cryptids to potentially have real, existing species be very similar, especially those in the oceans. if the giant squid exists, maybe there's a species out there similar to bigfoot, or mothman, or a sea serpent, or pretty much anything else. if we want to be really bold, we could even say that there's potential for something similar to the rake to be out there  our world, and more importantly to my argument, the ocean, is such a vast place. there's corners everywhere that possibly nobody has even bothered to check, and even some that, when checked, nobody ever came back to tell the tale. the kraken is so amazing and interesting to me because it has a real world counterpart, something that isn't just myths and folklore, but something we know for a fact exists. thats something most, if any cryptids at all, don't have  so much of the ocean is completely untouched by humanity, there's a lot of things in those waters that we don't know exist here with us. the mystery of what the ocean could entail, the existence of the giant squid, and the stories about the kraken all combine to completely flare up the already incredible discussion about cryptids. if we didn't know the giant squid existed, I would agree with B tier. but it's existence alone causes not just the kraken, but cryptids as a whole to burn brighter than ever before  but, at the end of the day, everyone is entitled to their own opinions. while I dont expect to change yours, I'm glad to at least have shared mine

I audibly yelled in excitement
And to think it was a terrible Tuesday till Wendi posted
You mention there not being much interesting about the Loch Ness Monster, but I actually think the history behind Nessie is even more interesting than the creature itself. That history being how rooted in the 1930s she is.  There's a common misconception that Nessie sightings go back a millennia to the days of Saint Columba, but this as mentioned is a misconception. The story of Saint Columba was one of him using the power of god to run off a "water beast" from the River Ness, not Loch Ness. Stories of water beasts were extraordinarily common during the times of early saints, and often used in stories as great obstacles for Saints or other holy men to overcome.   The only other sightings from pre 1933 are a very brief and not very detailed account from 1888 which described a creature that suspiciously resembled a salamander, and a reported sighting in 1871, however this sighting was not publicized until 1934 after the monster had become popular.   The actual sightings began in 1933, with the most prominent being George Spicer. There was one sighting before Spicer which described a pretty undetailed account of a blob like creature in the water. It's pretty unspecific and we don't know much about it. Spicer however gave a detailed account of the creature, and that account was of the plesiosaur like creature we know, and that's what stuck from then on.  Why is this interesting? Well it's because of George Spicer himself. What I and most historians believe (historians who investigate things like historical myths and mysteries) is that the Spicer sighting was fueled by cinema. In 1933, coincidentally just a couple weeks BEFORE the first modern sighting of the Loch Ness Monster, the movie King Kong was released in Spicer's hometown of London. There is a famous scene from this movie where a long necked creature rises out of the water of a swamp and attacks a character, eventually killing them. I do not think it to be mere coincidence that sightings started after this movie's release. Especially not since when asked about this, Spicer ADMITTED that he and his wife had gone to see King Kong shortly before their sighting.  This started a wave of sightings of plesiosaur creatures not just in Scotland, but from all over the world where King Kong was screened. I think this above anything is definitive proof that this creature was made up by a public who had just watched a disturbing and even scary movie scene with an exact looking creature.  Also, this is a much shorter way of proving the Loch Ness Monster isn't real, but the image and description we have of Nessie only matches what a plesiosaur looked like in 1933. Just like other dinosaurs, Paleontologists and scientists have a much different outlook on what a plesiosaur would have looked like. Nessie looks like what we thought a plesiosaur was like in 1933, but we no longer believe that.
Just fyi, the thylacine is actually pronouced thigh-la-seen not thigh-la-sign
